verses.text: 良人暫別佳偶我的妹妹，我的新婦啊！我進了我的園中；我採了我的沒藥與香料；我吃了我的蜂房與蜂蜜；我喝了我的酒和奶。朋友們！你們要開懷吃喝；親愛的啊！你們要不醉無歸。

words.note: A term of endearment for one's beloved spouse, often in biblical context.
A poetic term for a lovely spouse or partner.
Used as a term of endearment in Song of Songs.
Aromatic resin, used as perfume or medicine, transliterated name.
More formal or literary than '和' (hé).
Lit. 'open one's heart', implying unreserved enjoyment.
Idiom implying to enjoy oneself thoroughly without restraint.

verses.text: 我身雖然睡臥，我心卻醒。這是我的良人的聲音，他敲著門說：「我的妹妹，我的佳偶，我的鴿子，我的完全人哪！求你給我開門；因為我的頭滿了露水，頭髮給夜露滴濕。」

words.note: A more formal or literary way to say 'my body'.
A more formal or literary way to say 'my heart'.
Used as a term of endearment in Song of Songs.
A common biblical term of endearment, symbolizing purity/gentleness.
A term of endearment, implying flawlessness or completeness.

verses.text: 我回答：「我脫了外衣，怎能再穿上呢？我洗了腳，怎能再弄髒呢？」
我的良人從門孔裡伸進手來，我的心因他大為激動。

words.note: A literary adverb indicating a large extent.

verses.text: 我起來，要給我的良人開門；我的兩手滴下沒藥，指頭滴下沒藥，滴在門閂上。
我親手給我的良人開門，我的良人卻已轉身走了；我發現他走了，差點昏倒；我到處找他，卻找不見，我呼叫他，他卻不回答。

words.note: Commonly used in Song of Songs to refer to the beloved.
Commonly used in Song of Songs to refer to the beloved.

verses.text: 城中的守衛巡邏的時候，找著我；他們打了我，傷了我；看守城牆的人奪去了我身上的外衣。

words.note: Forms a temporal clause with 時候.

verses.text: 耶路撒冷的眾女子啊！我囑咐你們：你們若遇見我的良人，你們要告訴他甚麼呢？你們要告訴他，我患了相思病。

words.note: Often used in biblical contexts to mean 'all' or 'multitude'.
Commonly used in Song of Songs to refer to the beloved.
Often used for suffering from an illness.

verses.text: 你這女子中最美麗的啊！你的良人比別人的良人有甚麼更可愛之處呢？你的良人比別人的良人有甚麼更可愛之處呢？以致你這樣囑咐我們呢？

words.note: Commonly used in Song of Songs to refer to the beloved.
Commonly used in Song of Songs to refer to the beloved.
Literary equivalent of '的地方'.
Commonly used in Song of Songs to refer to the beloved.
Commonly used in Song of Songs to refer to the beloved.
Literary equivalent of '的地方'.

words.definition: so that, with the result that

verses.text: 佳偶稱讚良人的俊美我的良人紅光滿面，是萬人中的表表者。

words.note: Literary term for a good partner, used here for the bride.
Commonly used in Song of Songs to refer to the beloved.
Literary term for male beauty, often used in older texts.
Commonly used in Song of Songs to refer to the beloved.
An idiom describing a healthy, radiant face.
A literary term for someone who stands out or is exemplary.

verses.text: 他的頭像精金，他的頭髮如棕樹枝厚密，像烏鴉那麼黑。

words.note: Often used for purity and value in the Bible.
More formal than 像 (xiàng).
Palm branches are symbolic in biblical contexts.

verses.text: 他的眼好像溪水旁的鴿子，在奶中洗淨，塑得合式。

words.note: Doves often symbolize purity and peace in the Bible.
Used as a postposition indicating 'in' or 'among'.
『得』 indicates the result or extent of an action.

verses.text: 他的兩頰如香花畦，又如香草臺；他的嘴唇像百合花，滴下沒藥汁。

words.note: Refers to both cheeks.
More formal than 像 (xiàng).
Specific type of garden plot for fragrant flowers.
More formal than 像 (xiàng).
A raised bed or platform for aromatic herbs/spices.
A flower often associated with purity and beauty.
Myrrh is a fragrant resin used in ancient times for perfume and anointing.

verses.text: 他的雙手像金管，鑲嵌著水蒼玉；他的軀體如象牙塊，周圍包著藍寶石。

words.note: Suggests smooth, precious, and cylindrical form.
『著』 indicates a continuous or sustained state.
A precious gemstone, often green or bluish-green.
Formal term for the human body or trunk.
More formal than 像 (xiàng).
Conveys smooth, precious, and solid appearance.
『著』 indicates a continuous state or action.
A precious blue gemstone.

verses.text: 他的雙腿像大理石柱，安放在精金的座上；他的容貌如黎巴嫩山，像佳美的香柏樹。

words.note: Conveys strength, whiteness, and elegance.
『在』 indicates the location where something is placed.
Often used for purity and value in the Bible.
Acts as a postposition indicating 'on'.
Refers to facial features and overall look.
More formal than 像 (xiàng).
A mountain range known for its cedars and beauty.
Often used in biblical descriptions of beauty or quality.
Cedars of Lebanon were famous for their grandeur and durability.

verses.text: 他的口甜蜜；他全然可愛。耶路撒冷的眾女子啊！這就是我的良人，我的朋友。

words.note: Indicates a complete state or manner.
Lit. 'can be loved'.
Often refers to young women or daughters in a collective sense.
Used to express surprise, admiration, or to soften a command.
Emphasizes the preceding information.
A poetic term for a spouse or beloved, common in the Song of Solomon.
